query: When restoring grasslands, how do the outcomes of simply disturbing the soil before seeding compare to removing the topsoil entirely?
relevant_summary: When restoring grasslands, removing the topsoil or turf before seeding has been shown to have several benefits compared to just disturbing the soil. One UK-based study found that removing turf before sowing seeds led to a greater richness of both grass and forb species in most cases when compared to simply disturbing the soil (3415). Other studies have shown that topsoil removal can also increase the similarity of the plant community to that of intact steppe (3415), increase overall plant species richness (3415) and the richness of sown plants (3415), and lead to a higher cover of planted species (3415). Two studies in the USA also found that topsoil removal increased the survival of seedlings and plants (3415). In one study, disturbing the soil with a rotovator and spreading clippings increased the number of heathland plants (1711), while other studies have shown that removing topsoil and adding seed or clippings can increase the cover of heathland plants or heather and gorse (1711). Topsoil removal can also help to reduce the cover of undesirable species, with one study finding it led to a lower cover of common knapweed (3415) and another finding it reduced the cover of perennial rye-grass (1711).

query: What are the documented effects of adding soil amendments like charcoal, sulphur, or carbon before or after seeding on grassland vegetation?
relevant_summary: One study in the Netherlands found that adding charcoal to the soil before sowing did not change overall plant biomass or grass cover, but it did increase the cover of legumes (3422). Two studies in the UK and the USA examined the effects of adding sulphur to the soil before seeding. One of these studies found that adding sulphur reduced plant species richness, while the other found no change in species richness (3428). One study found that adding sulphur reduced overall vegetation cover (3428). In one study, low amounts of sulphur increased the cover of three of six sown species (3428). Another study found that adding sulphur did not alter the cover of native plant species (3428). Five trials in China and India found higher microbial biomass and activity in soils with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers, and four of these studies also found more organic carbon in the soil with these mixed fertilizers (902). One trial in India found that mixed amendments were more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil than inorganic fertilizers alone or no fertilizer (902). Two trials in China found increased maize yield in soils with mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments (902).
